title: Plethodon
text:
Plethodon is a genus of <a href="salamander">salamander</a>s in the family <a href="Plethodontidae">Plethodontidae</a>. They are also known as woodland salamanders or, more rarely, slimy salamanders. All members of the genus are <a href="endemic">endemic</a> to North America (Canada and USA). They have no aquatic larval stage. In some species, such as "<a href="Plethodon%20cinereus">Plethodon cinereus</a>", the red-backed salamander, eggs are laid underneath a stone or log. Young hatch in the adult form. Members of "Plethodon" primarily eat small invertebrates. The earliest known fossils of this genus are from the <a href="Hemphillian">Hemphillian</a> of <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a> in the United States.
Species.
There are 56 species in the genus "Plethodon". Listed in alphabetical order of <a href="specific%20name%20%28zoology%29">specific name</a>:
"<a href="Nota%20bene">Nota bene</a>": A <a href="Binomial%20nomenclature">binomial authority</a> in parentheses indicates that the species was originally described in a genus other than "Plethodon".
